caption:
The photograph captures a middle-aged man, likely a bus driver, sitting in the driver's seat inside a bus. He is focused on writing on a clipboard that rests on his lap. The man wears a white shirt and dark pants. Notably, he has a tattoo on his left forearm and wears dark-rimmed glasses.

The driver's environment includes various controls indicative of an older model bus. The dashboard in front of him holds numerous dials and switches, along with a large steering wheel. A metal thermos sits next to him, suggesting that he might be preparing for a long shift or recording details during a break.

In the background, visible through the front windshield and the open door of the bus, is a sunny day with a clear view of a road lined by green trees, hinting at a suburban setting. The external view suggests it's daytime with fair weather conditions, providing a serene backdrop to the specifics of the bus interior. The bus appears to be parked as indicated by the views through the windows and the relaxed demeanor of the man.
title: Driver for the dial a rider radio dispatched door-to-door bus service in Haddonfield, New Jersey, writes down his next pickup point.  The service began in february, 1972, as a demonstration project between federal and state departments of transportation funding ended in march, 1975.  Spokesmen reported it worked well in rush hour along fixed routes.  But the 30-cent fare wasn't enough to cover one to three persons picked up at home in off hours
